title: How did the Ahoms beat Mughals? - Quora

response.answer_text: What are the factors that increase the success rate of a battle? Better TechnologyLarger Army strengthWealth (To bribe) the enemy commandersAll these factors sided with the Mughals, then why were they defeated? The answer is that they did not have Lachit Borphukan, the legendary Ahom general and a contemporary of Shivaji Maharaj. Let’s see how he nullified the above factors which would have given a clear advantage to the Mughals with his military acumen: Lachit was quite familiar with the terrain of the North East. He knew that he had no chance of thwarting a Mughal attack on land. So he built mud embankments to halt land invasions. He knew how to exploit Mughals’ lack of experience in naval warfares and made a stronghold in Guwahati on the banks of Brahmaputra river. Thus he nullified the heavy Mughal cannons that were hard to deploy in such a terrain. Lachit trapped the Mughals in a narrow region (as seen above) and thus rendered their larger size useless.Lachit introduced several reforms among his men which reduced the corruption in the army. When he found his maternal uncle relaxing instead of completing the fortifications, as he had been instructed for the upcoming war, he famously exclaimed “dexh t ke mumai dangor nohoi”, which means “my uncle is not greater than my motherland”. Like Shivaji, he was a staunch patriot who placed his countrymen above his family. His execution of his own uncle for not showing sufficient dedication to the war effort was not just an act of impulse but a reminder to his soldiers that in the service of one’s Dharma, it is not possible to adopt double standards of judgment. These actions reduced the corruption in the Ahom army drastically. He even set a personal example by refusing to accept a bribe when the Mughals offered it to him.Battle of Saraighat (Source: Wikipedia) During the last stage of the Battle of Saraighat, when the Mughals attacked by the Brahmaputra river, the Ahom soldiers began to lose their will to fight. Some even retreated. Though Lachit was seriously ill he boarded a boat and with seven boats advanced against the Mughal fleet. He said: "If you (the soldiers) want to flee, flee. The king has given me a task here and I will do it well. Let the Mughals take me away. You report to the king that his general fought well following his orders". His soldiers rallied and a desperate battle started. Lachit Barphukan was victorious. The Mughals were forced to retreat. These characteristics of Lachit Borphukan like leading his army from the front earned him respect even from his enemies. The Mughal commander Ram Singh, who tried numerous times to bribe Lachit, praised his bravery in the battle: ‘Glory to the king! Glory to the counselors! Glory to the commanders! Glory to the country! One single individual leads all the forces! Even I, Ram Singh, being personally on the spot, have not been able to find any loophole and an opportunity!’ Such was the Charisma of the brave Ahom general who protected the North East from the tyranny of Mughals!!  Other Forgotten Bravehearts: Kashmir's AlexanderIndia's Napolean vs Europe’s Samudragupta?Hammir Dev Chauhan- The warrior who challenged Khiljis.Forgotten warriors of OdishaPeshwa Madhavrao- The 16-year-old Maratha gemPeshwa Bajirao, the most badass strategist warrior in Indian history.Rana Sanga, the one-eyed warrior who humiliated the Sultans.Durgadas Rathore, the warrior who challenged Aurangzeb in his own court.Chandrasen Rathore, the King as defiant as Maharana Pratap or Shivaji Maharaj but not that popular.Raja Bhoja, the king who ended the peril of Ghazni.The brothers who ended the Delhi’s subjugation of South India.Other forgotten Bravehearts

Social structure and motivation Social structure of Assam was not based on feudalism. It followed a Paik system system where ordinary citizens or pikes had to serve the king for some period as tax. Land was property of state and the pikes were given their own land right. Personnel land ownership meant more attachment to the land and increased willingness to defend the country. Moreover, most of the constituent groups of Assam had strong tribal characteristics. Such a society encourages cohesive in its members and combined with land ownership generates a sense of what we call nationalism today. Hence, against an external army the Assamese people fought their own war to defend their own, instead of fighting for some landlord or king. In contrast, the Mughals forces contained mercenaries and vessel kings who were actually fighting somebody else’s war. Guerrilla warfare The Assamese soldiers took full advantages of the terrain, which is very familiar to them. Saraighat was an ideal place to pinch down a large attacking force - being surrounded by hills, forests and low laying land, the Mughal navy had to pass a narrow section of Brahmaputra providing a “guerrilla heaven” for the highly motivated Assamese soldiers expert in guerrilla warfare. As two Turkish mercenary leaders fall, their soldiers started to flee and the win was easy. Mobility Mughal navy had large boats difficult to maneuver in the already narrow section of the Brahmaputra. In contrast, Assamese used smaller boats in so large numbers that could overwhelm the Mughal navy quickly. Inspirational Leadership Lachit Borphukan was an excellent general who lead by example. Especially the incident of him beading his own uncle for lapse in duty, earned him huge respect. Flanked by advisers like Aton Burhagohain and supported by excellent lieutenants like Bagh Hazarika he was leading a highly motivated army. His last act, when he himself took the lead of the last charge at Saraighat in spite of being very ill, no other push was required for the nationalistic Assamese force.

To begin with, Mughals were never good in guriella and jungle-mountain warfare, it's one aspect where they always struggled in, whether be it against the Ahoms, the Marathas in the Western Ghats or against Rana Pratap after he lost the battle of Haldighati and had to retreat to the Aravalli hill with the support of the Bhil tribesmen. Mughal Army's forte was in innovative manoeuver warfare using horses and elephants, ably supported by Artillery Canons in the plains. Mughals were also very inexperienced in riverine warfare. And they had no navy worth boasting of. The main strike to conquer Assam came during Aurangzeb's reign. The mughal imperial army was led by a famous Rajput General, Raja Man Singh of Amber. Guru Teg Bahadur also accompanied Raja Man Singh on this expedition as a punishment decreed by Auranzeb. Guru Teg Bahadur tried to play the role of a diplomat, by urging the Ahom King and Raja Man Singh to arrive at an amicable settlement. However, diplomatic negotiations failed and the full scale invasion was inevitable. The Mughal Army was huge. Ably supported by Canons and cavalry. Legend has it that when informed by spies about the huge size of the invading mughal army, the great Assamese General, Lachit Borphukan was moved to tears and his resolve to fight till death was strengthened many times over. Now, Lachit Borphukan was a master strategist. He knew, havoc would break upon Assam if the Mughal Army were to reach the plains. So instead of letting the Mughals bring the battle to him, he chose the battlefield. The Ahom Forces strategically retreated from the border outposts, and let the Mughal Army come in. The mughal army here won some minor battles. Now, because of the hilly terrain and the heavy artillery brought by the Mughals, canvassing through the hills was near impossible. The mughal Army chose the only easy way possible to enter the plains of Assam - through the Brahmaputra river by boats. In this Lachit Borphukan found the sweet spot. He decided to fortify the hills adjoining the riverside and ambush the traveling mughal party by a flotilla of Asom Navy boats armed with Cannons. ( A side story - During the fortification, his mama - ie mother's brother was in charge of a fort and had neglected to do his duty of fortification. Enraged, Lachit Borphukan beheaded his uncle for his lapse in duty). Lachit Borphukan then ambushed the travelling Mughal Army in Guwahati's Saraighat. Kamakhya Temple Hill ( Known as Nilachal Hills) was the focal point and from it, nowadays, IIT Guwahati can be seen. The ahom forces were arranged in a triangular manner. The main vanguard flotilla of boats was led by Lachit Barphukan himself, who although being very ill took part in the Battle. The mughal force was ambushed from 3 sides and took a battering. To a big extent the invasion force ceased to exist as a coherent fighting force and retreated.  In the pic, notice how carefully Lachit Borphukan had chosen the ambush site at the narrowest part of the Brahmaputra river. Now, althrough the Mughals had been routed in Saraighat, they still had some territory left in northwards of Guwahati. After the battle of Saraighat, a mini civil war took place in Assam wherin the rightful ahom King, Gadadhar Singha had to flee and take refugee in Nagaland. In this period, the efforts to expel the Mughals from Assam were limited. However, when Gadadhar Singha took back his rightful throne, he amassed a huge army to expel the Mughals out of Assam. Already broken by the Battle of Saraighat and at the end of their supply lines, the Mughal Army remnants couldn't fight and the local Mugal Faujdar fled, ending the Mughal saga in Assam. PS - In National Defence Academy Khadakwasla, there is an award called Lachit Borphukan award which is given to the best performing cadet.

The Mughals were beaten in 1671 in battle of Saraighat.The Ahoms spanned the Brahmaputra by an improvised bridge of boats placed side by side. They also resorted to a wily trick, combining a frontal charge with a surprise attack from behind, that proved decisive. The Barphukan pretended to attack the Mughal fleet from the front with some men on a few ships and lure it forward and then stabbed it from behind with the main army and fleet….The Mughal admiral, Sarif Khan, smoking his hooka, advanced forward only to be killed by a gunshot from behind. The suddenness of the event threw the entire Moghul fleet out of gear and it retreated. The panic-stricken Mughal army could not be recalled to order. His death marked the end of the battle. After his defeat, Ram Singh of Amber, commander of Aurangzeb’s army, wrote to the Emperor: “Every Assamese soldier is expert in rowing boats, shooting arrows, digging trenches and in wielding guns and cannons. I have not seen such specimens of versatility in any other part of India. Glory to the King. Glory to the Commander. One single individual leads all the forces. Even I, Ram Singh, being personally on the spot, have not been able to find any loophole.” The Barphukan’s victory is recorded in a stone inscription in Guwahati. The best cadet officer of every batch graduating from the National Defence Academy gets the Lachit Barphukan Gold Medal.

So called mighty and barbaric was not so much mighty. Ancient days there were huge logistic problems. 2/3 of the Army was just occupied for this logistics. If the distance is anything more than hundred kilometer it was taking months to mobilize army. Indian monsoon also a big problem for outside armies. Assam was just a terrific terrain. Hills and rivers. Rivers are so mighty like brahmaputra you can not cross it without full knowledge of the area. In old days if the leader of the army has die or even having sickness means entire expedition d stined to fail. Combining this if local kings were not with mughals or in that case British then they were never able to concurr an square inch of land. It was the combined forces who won wars. So actually Mughal was not a Muslim army but an alliance of lical +out siders. Local allience members were not interested in concurring Ahoms of Assam. So Mughal were not successful.
